channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: 25 Years After Oklahoma City, Domestic Terrorism Is On The Rise
item.description: In an exclusive interview with WIRED, FBI director Christopher Wray discusses a scourge that "moves at the speed of social media."

item.title: Watching This Milling Machine Carve A Miniature Topographic Map Of Mount Rainier Out Of Aluminum Is Oddly Satisfying
item.description: Witness the mighty power of the Desktop PCB Milling Machine as it wittles an aluminum cube into a replica of Mount Rainier.
item.kicker: MAKING A MOUNTAIN OUT OF A MOLEHILL

item.title: Everyone Is Baking — And Entrepreneurs Are Rising Up To Meet The Demand
item.description: A look behind the numbers driving the latest quarantine craze and the small businesses that are filling a gap in the market.

item.title: Watch This Stand-Off, In Colorado, Between A Protester And Healthcare Worker
item.description: "Two nurses, who have witnessed first hand the toll Covid is taking in Colorado, stood up and peacefully counter protested. Here is how they were treated. I had join them."

item.title: Inside The Ship That Stands Watch Over The Melting Arctic
item.description: You can tell the Norwegian research vessel Johan Hjort is made for the Arctic because it holds a tanning bed inside.

item.title: End-Of-Life Planning During The Coronavirus Pandemic, In Eight Steps
item.description: How to make crucial financial and health care decisions for you and your loved ones.

item.title: The Boat Launch May Be Frozen, But That Doesn't Mean You Can't Load A Boat Like This Guy
item.description: Frozen times call for desperate measures.

item.title: Tax Incentives And The Human Imagination
item.description: It would be interesting to look at locations of the American popular imagination, as seen in movies and TV, mapped against regional tax breaks for the film industry.

item.title: The Many Languages Missing From The Internet
item.description: English and a handful of other languages dominate the internet, but this is leaving indigenous cultures without a voice online. Now they are fighting back.

item.title: Remembering The Time United Airlines Offered A Men-Only Flight
item.description: From 1953 through 1970, United offered men-only 'Executive flights' — something you might see on an episode of "Mad Men."

item.title: 'Who Wants To Be A Millionaire' Wants To Be A Megahit Again
item.description: ABC has rolled out a celebrity edition of what was once the most popular program on television, this time helmed by Jimmy Kimmel. Can the game show become a hit again?

item.title: Steve Mnuchin Thinks The Economy Will Bounce Back In 'Months.' That's Very Unlikely
item.description: The treasury secretary's sunny predictions are at odds with mainstream economic forecasting.

item.title: It's Actually A Great Time To Try To Sell A TV Show
item.description: How Hollywood is adapting to the pandemic.
item.kicker: TIME TO OPEN UP THE DRAFT FOLDER

item.title: Colorado: Images of the Centennial State
item.description: A few glimpses of Colorado's landscape and some of the animals and people calling it home.
item.kicker: HIGH PLAINS TO THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS

item.title: Kinetic Artist Builds Rube Goldberg Machine For Passing The Pepper While Social Distancing At The Dinner Table
item.description: Joseph Herscher has a clever way of getting the pepper with a very elaborate contraption.

item.title: Protesting For The Right To Catch The Coronavirus
item.description: The reopen America protests are the logical conclusion of a twisted liberty movement.

item.title: Massive Wild Animals Wander Russian Streets In These Surreal Composites By Vadim Solovyov
item.description: Seeing a raccoon washing its paws in the rivers of Saint Petersburg or an octopus tumbling out of a city bus would be a startling sight for most city dwellers.

item.title: Dog Walker Finds Clever Way To Stay Safe When Out-And-About In The Neighborhood
item.description: Just a typical day in Nashua, New Hampshire.

item.title: Safe As Houses
item.description: Americans have always designed our living spaces to respond to threats both real and imagined.

item.title: Seoul's Full Cafes, Apple Store Lines Show Mass Testing Success
item.description: Cafes bustled with customers, parks teemed with sunbathers, and the first Apple store to reopen outside China had lines snaking out the door as many South Koreans — almost all wearing masks — emerged from months of self-isolation.

item.title: This Harvard Epidemiologist Is Very Popular On Twitter. But Does He Know What He's Talking About?
item.description: Eric Feigl-Ding has been making the rounds on TV as a coronavirus expert. Some of his colleagues think he's unqualified.

item.title: Why Would Someone Steal The World's Rarest Water Lily? (2014)
item.description: In January 2014, an endangered plant was taken from Kew Gardens — only a few years after scientists saved it from extinction. Sam Knight investigates what happens when plant obsession turns criminal.

item.title: Michael Jordan Art Directed His Most Iconic Dunk By Himself
item.description: Michael Jordan helped out the veteran photographer Walter Iooss Jr. after telling him which way he was going to dunk in the contest. That tip led Iooss Jr. to capture an iconic moment in MJ's career.

item.title: Pokémon Go Adds Remote Raids So You Don't Have To Go Outside
item.description: Niantic is adding a new item called a Remote Raid Pass to Pokémon Go, letting you play raids that appear on the app's map or "Nearby" page without having to go to the physical location.

item.title: Keirin School: Inside The Strict And Secret World Of Bicycle Racing In Japan
item.description: Keirin racing in Japan is a big business that is rich in traditions too. Its intriguing world says a lot about our Olympics hosts.

item.title: Somebody Hacked Their iPad Pro To Run Mac OS X
item.description: A tech whiz found a way to run Mac OS X Leopard 10.5 on an emulator on their 2020 iPad Pro 11″ without Jailbreaking it.

item.title: Perfect Your Family Game Night With This Co-Op Card Game
item.description: This game starts with three to six players getting stranded in a plane crash. Now, you all have to work together to survive. It only takes about 15 minutes to play a round, and it's suited for players ages 10 and up.

item.title: Ventilators Aren't Going To Cure COVID-19. Here's What They Can Do
item.description: Since the beginning of the coronavirus outbreak, ventilators have been a key focus of the media, politicians and the president. But most of these references miss some key points.

item.title: How Orange Juice Lost Its Popularity In American Culture
item.description: The popularity of orange juice is, surprisingly, a product of clever marketing. But why have Americans fallen out of love with this drink in recent years?

item.title: Scientists Are Racing To Get Us Faster, Simpler Coronavirus Tests
item.description: Rapid and at-home tests could give results in minutes rather than days.

item.title: Why Americans Are Too Angry To Fix The American Dream
item.description: We cannot survive as a nation where ZIP code is destiny.

item.title: Here's A Hilarious Cut Of Misheard Pop Song Lyrics That All Center Around Food
item.description: And now that we've heard this, we can never un-hear it again.

item.title: Telemedicine Is Not Enough
item.description: It's 2020, and millions of Americans — now bound to their homes — still don't have reliable internet access. In a pandemic, that's a public health crisis.

item.title: A Gallery Of Stunning Photos Of Classic Range Rover Conversions
item.description: The Range Rover has been a notable part of motoring since the beginning of the 1970s.

item.title: The Slow Mo Guys Attempt To Break The Upper Limit Of YouTube's Compression Algorithm
item.description: Can the Slow Mo Guys break your YouTube?

item.title: How Does One Actually Go About Becoming a LEGO Master?
item.description: "LEGO Masters" finalists Boone and Mark explain how they built their legacies.

item.title: A Biblical Nightmare Strikes The Horn Of Africa
item.description: Locust swarms are multiplying in eastern Africa as farmers plant their next harvest and the coronavirus threat grows.

item.title: Genius Designed A Basketball Hoop Where The Ball Always Goes In
item.description: A YouTuber wrote some software to come up with the most optimal basketball backboard possible and then built it.

item.title: Spain's Strangest Hotspots, And More Best Photography Of The Week
item.description: Living inside Brazil's largest apartment complex amid a pandemic, prophetic images of an empty world and other best photos of the week.

item.title: Keep The House Clean Without Making Too Much Noise
item.description: This robotic vacuum from Eufy has nearly 15,000 reviews on Amazon, and still has an impressive 4.5/5 average.

item.title: We Aren't Sure Whether This Potato Chip Omelette Hack Is The Worst Idea Ever Or Something Fun To Try
item.description: The food influencers at Chefclub came up with this, er, unconventional way to cook a Crispy Potato Chip Omelette, which is being hailed online as either brilliant or a crime against humanity.

item.title: A Beloved Bar Owner Was Skeptical About The Virus. Then He Took A Cruise
item.description: Joe Joyce oversaw JJ Bubbles, a welcoming tavern in a conservative corner of Brooklyn, for 43 years until he died of Covid-19.

item.title: Spending A Lot Of Time Cooking? Cut Down On Meal Prep With The Instant Pot Duo
item.description: Cook up large portions over the weekend, and your lunch is taken care of for the rest of the week.

item.title: Gymnast Breaks The Matrix, Pulls Off A True Standing Double Backflip On Grass
item.description: Kaleb Cave seems to have pulled off a true standing double backflip on grass. It's wild

item.title: The Quiet Revolution Of Animal Crossing
item.description: In the midst of a pandemic, it's delightful to imagine doing whatever you like without worrying about making a living.

item.title: The Occupations With The Highest Risk Of Coronavirus Exposure, Visualized
item.description: According to this chart from Visual Capitalist, some US workers are more susceptible to putting themselves in harm's way.

item.title: Los Angeles Fills Venice Skate Park With Sand In An Effort To Keep Skateboarders Out During Quarantine
item.description: The county beach workers filled up the Venice Skatepark with sand.
